activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] Memory scoring formula: exponential decay + access boost + failure penalty
activities.details: Scoring: decay = e^(-lambda * ageDays) where lambda varies by type (fact:0.04, pain:0.025, win:0.015, decision:0.008, arch:0.004). Plus accessBoost (recency of last access), freqBonus (log2 of accessCount), minus failurePenalty (0.15 per correlated failure), minus supersededPenalty (0.6). Health classification: active (>0.5), aging (0.25-0.5), stale (<0.25), harmful (2+ failure correlations), superseded. Review queue surfaces stale/harmful to Pat. Contradiction detection at write time via tag overlap (2+ shared tags + same type). Research sources: A-Mem, MemEngine, SimpleMem, Letta.

activities.description: Task: Implement memory scoring module (82-line TypeScript)
activities.details: Write packages/core/src/brain/scoring.ts with: scoreMemory(), classifyHealth(), rankMemories(), getReviewQueue(), findContradictions(). Add lastAccessedAt, accessCount, failureCorrelations, supersededBy fields to Memory schema. Integrate into hw_retrieve_memories for filtered/ranked results. Formula: exponential decay (type-specific rates) + access boost + freq bonus - failure penalty - superseded penalty. Half-lives: fact 17d, pain 28d, win 46d, decision 87d, architecture 173d.

activities.description: Task: Crash-safety sentinel: buddy-spawned hidden process that survives crashes
activities.details: Redesign the watcher system as a persistent crash-safety sentinel. Buddy spawns a hidden Node.js process (windowsHide: true) on startup that polls the Tauri PID. On app death (crash or clean exit), sentinel runs recovery: backup state files, write crash-marker.json, preserve activity log. Buddy shows a shield indicator (lit=polling, dark=inactive). If sentinel dies, buddy respawns it. Replaces the per-task app_shutdown_copy pattern. Needs: (1) Rust command in lib.rs to spawn hidden process and report app PID, (2) sentinel.mjs script that polls and runs recovery, (3) BuddyOverlay shield indicator with health check, (4) SessionStart hook reads crash-marker.json on next boot.

activities.description: Decision: Watcher system: repurpose from per-task file copies to persistent crash-safety sentinel
activities.details:
Chosen: Redesign watchers as a single persistent crash-safety sentinel spawned by buddy on startup. Hidden process (no console window), polls Tauri PID, runs recovery on crash/exit. Visual indicator on buddy shows sentinel health. Replaces dozens of per-task throwaway watchers with one always-on guardian.
The sentinel survives crashes (detached process), is invisible to the user (windowsHide), and provides crash recovery that no in-process hook can offer. Buddy is the natural owner since it's the persistent visual element. For worktree Rust merges, manual file copy is simpler and more reliable.

activities.details:
Quality: 4 tension, 2 shifted, 1 consensus
  1. [TENSION] What is the canonical Memory schema? Which new fields are essential (links, reflections, qualityScore, fingerprint, supersededBy) and which are overengineering? What's the minimal schema that supports linking, scoring, dedup, and conflict resolution? -> Schema adds: links[], supersededBy, qualityScore, fingerprint (all optional). New type enum: reflection. Optional reflection fields: relatedTaskId, surfacedMemoryIds, outcome.
  2. [TENSION] What is the complete retrieval pipeline from 'user types message' to 'brain injects context'? How do scoring.ts, cortex learning, link traversal, and context phase integrate into one flow? Where does each team's contribution slot in? -> 11-stage pipeline: tokenize, attention, cortex load (merged), pattern recognition, associative chaining, link traversal (0.8/0.6/0.4 weights), amygdala * scoreMemory * synapticStrength, rank with context phase, forced pain-win pairing via resolves links, dopamine, hot tags. Telemetry on every retrieval.
  3. [SHIFTED] How does the brain learn from outcomes? Design the complete feedback loop: memory surfaced -> task outcome -> strength adjustment -> rule derivation. How do Reflexion-style reflections, Hebbian plasticity, and engineering effectiveness tracking combine into one system? -> Complete feedback loop: surfaced -> activeTraces -> task completion -> reflection (template-based) -> outcome-based plasticity (+0.15 success, -0.05 failure) -> after 3+ reflections same tags -> derive learned rule -> confidence scoring -> CLAUDE.md promotion at 0.9+. Prediction-error principle for auto-capture.
  4. [SHIFTED] What enters the brain automatically vs manually? Design quality gates, dedup rules, and the prediction-error principle. How do we prevent auto-capture noise (71 of 193 memories are low-quality auto-captured) while still capturing important events? -> Three-gate quality system: qualityScore at write (reject < 0.15), fingerprint dedup (block exact, warn near), conflict resolution (ADD/MERGE/INVALIDATE/SKIP). Auto-capture uses prediction-error: only store unexpected outcomes. Expected success = just boost, novel success = capture, failure despite warnings = capture reflection.
  5. [CONSENSUS] How does the brain self-evolve? Design cortex learning (auto-expand keyword map), procedural memory (learned rules from patterns), and automated archival/pruning. What self-evolves vs what stays manual? Where is the automation boundary? -> Three self-evolution systems: (1) cortex learning from retrieval gaps + memory title mining at PreCompact, (2) automated pruning at session end (stale + zero-access + 60d = archive), (3) learned rules derived from reflection patterns with confidence scoring. Cortex-learned.json, learned-rules.json, memories-archive.json.
  6. [TENSION] How do we enforce brain signals so Claude can't ignore them? Design the three-layer enforcement: signal (hook output format), gate (PreToolUse blocks), instruction (CLAUDE.md rules). What's mandatory vs advisory? -> Three-layer enforcement: signal (hook prefixes [ATTENTION GATE], [CRITICAL PAIN], [LEARNED RULE]), gate (PreToolUse blocks Edit/Write when smart checkpoint triggers -- significantEvents >= 3 AND interval exceeded), instruction (CLAUDE.md rules). Brain health observability via hw_brain_health tool + memory-metrics.json.
  7. [TENSION] What is the phased execution plan? Map every feature to a specific phase, identify dependencies, and define what ships in session 48 vs 49 vs 50+. What's the minimum viable brain that delivers real learning, and what layers on top? -> 4-session phased execution. S48: migration script + unify systems + wire engine + scoring + plasticity (~800 lines). S49: quality gates + reflections + linking (~600 lines). S50: cortex learning + pruning + rules (~500 lines). S51: enforcement + observability + flowchart (~300 lines). Total ~2200 lines across 4 new files + modifications to ~10 existing files.

activities.details:
MAGNUM OPUS BRAIN DESIGN -- Unified architecture from 3 think tank teams.

SCHEMA: Memory adds links[], supersededBy, qualityScore, fingerprint. New type "reflection" with optional relatedTaskId, surfacedMemoryIds, outcome fields.

PIPELINE (11 stages): tokenize -> attention filter -> cortex load (DEFAULT + learned) -> pattern recognition -> associative chaining -> link traversal (resolves=0.8, extends=0.6, related=0.4) -> amygdala * scoreMemory() * synapticStrength -> context-phase rank -> forced pain-win pairing via resolves links -> dopamine -> hot tags. Telemetry on every retrieval.

LEARNING LOOP: surfaced memories tracked in activeTraces -> task completion generates template-based reflection -> outcome-based plasticity (+0.15 success, -0.05 failure) -> 3+ reflections same tags -> derive learned rule -> confidence scoring -> CLAUDE.md promotion at 0.9+.

QUALITY SYSTEM: qualityScore at write (reject < 0.15), fingerprint dedup, conflict resolution (ADD/MERGE/INVALIDATE/SKIP). Prediction-error auto-capture: only store unexpected outcomes.

SELF-EVOLUTION: cortex learning from retrieval gaps + title mining, automated pruning at session end, learned rules from reflection patterns. Three new files: cortex-learned.json, learned-rules.json, memories-archive.json.

ENFORCEMENT: Three layers -- signal (hook prefixes), gate (PreToolUse blocks on smart checkpoints: significantEvents >= 3 AND interval), instruction (CLAUDE.md rules). hw_brain_health observability tool.

EXECUTION: 4 sessions, ~2200 lines total. S48: migration + unification + wiring + scoring + plasticity. S49: quality gates + reflections + linking. S50: cortex learning + pruning + rules. S51: enforcement + observability + flowchart.

activities.description: [FACT] Research synthesis: AI memory systems -- our brain MO is research-aligned
activities.details: 6-agent deep research (S53) studied Cursor, Windsurf, Claude Code, academic papers, practitioner patterns, and anti-patterns. Key findings: (1) Industry converges on plain markdown for CODING memory, but our use case is broader -- persistent relational memory across sessions. (2) Quality gates and pruning are research-proven essential (Xiong et al.: indiscriminate storage degrades agents by 10%). (3) Our linker aligns with A-MEM Zettelkasten approach (superior results on 6 models). (4) Plasticity/decay aligns with MemoryBank and Mnemosyne (both show improvements). (5) Rules extraction is memory consolidation (episodic to semantic), theoretically sound. (6) 52 sessions is barely a warm-up -- benchmarks run hundreds of interactions. (7) Letta found plain filesystem beat Mem0 graph on LoCoMo (74% vs 68.5%) but this measures coding context, not long-term relationship memory.

activities.description: [FACT] Competitor analysis: Cursor, Windsurf, Claude Code memory approaches (Feb 2026)
activities.details: Cursor: 3 layers (rules files with glob patterns, cloud Memories via Gemini sidecar needing privacy mode off, codebase vector indexing). Chat history lost between sessions. Community built Memory Bank workarounds. Windsurf: workspace-scoped auto-memories (no pruning, no expiration, SpAIware security vuln), custom hybrid retrieval (dense+sparse, sub-20ms), community built replacement (cascade-memory-bank 600+ stars). Claude Code: CLAUDE.md hierarchy with 200-line auto-memory cap, session memory summaries, compaction at 95%. None of them solve long-term relationship memory -- all focus on coding conventions and project context.

activities.description: [FACT] Academic memory research: what works for LLM agents (2024-2026)
activities.details: Key papers and findings: A-MEM (Zettelkasten linking, superior on 6 models), MemRL (RL-trained memory beats RAG +82%), Mem0 (26% over OpenAI Memory, 90% token reduction), Xiong et al. (indiscriminate storage = 10% decline, selective addition + deletion = 10% gain), MemoryBank (Ebbinghaus forgetting curves), Mnemosyne (hybrid scoring sub-ms retrieval), episodic memory called 'missing piece' (ICML 2025). Anti-patterns: memory poisoning real even from benign staleness, Hebbian reinforcement amplifies confabulation, ALMA meta-learned designs outperform hand-crafted. SimpleMem compression beat complex retrieval 26.4% F1.

activities.description: Task: Design automatic memory capture -- detect and store significant moments
activities.details: The brain stores memories only when Claude manually calls hw_store_memory. Significant moments (understanding shifts, Pat corrections, research conclusions, decisions) go uncaptured. Design a system that detects these moments and triggers automatic storage. Research: what hooks can we use (PreCompact, Stop, hippocampal timer), what conversation signals indicate a significant moment, what format should auto-captured memories take. This is the missing piece that makes the brain actually learn.

activities.description: [FACT] Pat's model preference: Sonnet 4.6 1M for subagents, Opus for coding
activities.details: All reasoning, research, and deliberation subagents should use model="sonnet" (Sonnet 4.6 1M context). All direct coding work stays on Opus. This is a cost/performance optimization -- Sonnet handles research and analysis well at lower cost.

activities.description: [WIN] Method: Deep research then reverse-engineer -- competitive intelligence pattern
activities.details: Two-phase research method. Phase 1: spawn 6 parallel agents to research a domain broadly (competitors, academic papers, practitioner experience, simple approaches, anti-patterns). Phase 2: take the specific tools/plugins/systems found in Phase 1 and spawn agents to reverse-engineer each one -- read source code, find flaws, bottlenecks, failure points, and room for improvement. The synthesis of Phase 2 gives us a blueprint for building something better than anything that exists. Used in S53 for AI memory systems: first 6 agents mapped the landscape, then 6 agents tore apart the 6 best community plugins.

activities.description: [WIN] Method: 6-agent parallel research sprint
activities.details: Spawn 6 agents simultaneously, each researching a different angle of the same question. Agents cover: direct competitors, adjacent competitors, academic state of the art, practitioner experience, simple approaches that work, and failure modes/anti-patterns. Results come back in ~3-4 minutes. Synthesis happens in the main thread. Used multiple times: S53 memory systems research, earlier competitive intel runs. Use Sonnet 4.6 1M for research agents to save cost.

activities.description: [WIN] Method: Multi-agent parallel build with worktrees
activities.details: For large non-overlapping code changes, spawn multiple agents each in an isolated git worktree. Each agent works on different files without conflicts. Merge manually where shared files overlap. Used in S48 Brain Magnum Opus (4-agent parallel build shipped the entire foundation) and S52 resilience task force (6 agents). Key: run migration scripts before code changes, disable old system AFTER new one is wired.

activities.description: [WIN] Method: 4-agent audit pattern (UI/UX + Architecture + Cognitive + Value/ROI)
activities.details: For auditing any significant feature or system, spawn 4 specialist agents in parallel: (1) UI/UX agent evaluates user experience and design, (2) Architecture agent evaluates code structure, patterns, and technical debt, (3) Cognitive agent evaluates mental model clarity and information hierarchy, (4) Value/ROI agent evaluates whether the feature justifies its complexity. Cross-referencing the 4 perspectives catches issues no single lens would find. Used for Brain Magnum Opus audit in S49.

activities.description: [WIN] Method: Deliberation system -- multi-agent debate with mediator for binding decisions
activities.details: For decisions that matter: plan sub-questions, get Pat's approval, run a multi-agent deliberation with cognitive modes (Contrarian, Pre-mortem, First Principles, Steelman, Analogist, Constraint). Mediator tracks coverage with quality tags (consensus/tension/shifted). Coverage check ensures every sub-question got substantive treatment. Conclusion requires synthesis. Used for state storage architecture (JSON vs SQLite), deliberation guardrails design, multi-project architecture. Separate from quick insights (non-binding, 2-4 agents, no sub-questions).

activities.description: [PAIN] Method caveat: 4-agent audit found issues but some were false positives
activities.details: The 4-agent audit pattern (UI/UX + Architecture + Cognitive + Value/ROI) used in S49 for Brain MO audit found real issues but also produced recommendations that were over-engineered or missed the mark. Some agents flagged theoretical problems that weren't practical concerns. The audit added value but results need critical filtering -- not every agent recommendation should be acted on.

activities.description: [PAIN] Method caveat: deliberation system produced groupthink on early runs
activities.details: Early deliberation runs had agents agreeing too quickly without substantive engagement. The mediator let agents lump and dismiss sub-questions. This was fixed with coverage quality tags (consensus/tension/shifted) and guardrails requiring substantive treatment of each sub-question. But even with guardrails, deliberation agents can produce sophisticated-sounding agreement that lacks real tension. The shifted tag (agent changed position) is the most valuable signal -- if no agents shift, the deliberation may not have pushed hard enough.

activities.description: [PAIN] Method caveat: parallel research agents can produce redundant or shallow results
activities.details: The 6-agent research sprint works well for breadth but agents sometimes return overlapping findings or surface-level summaries when the topic requires depth. The first S53 research run produced a "debbie downer" synthesis that was too quick to trash our own work based on shallow comparisons (comparing our relational memory system against coding-assistant memory). Research agents need precise, narrow prompts -- broad prompts produce broad, sometimes misleading results.

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] Reverse-engineering synthesis: 6 community memory plugins -- flaws and opportunities
activities.details: S53 reverse-engineered 6 plugins: claude-memory (deterministic triage), claude-mem (SQLite+Chroma), claude-diary (PreCompact reflection), auto-memory (file tracking), arscontexta (6-phase Zettelkasten), memory-mcp (chunked extraction). Universal flaws found: (1) No feedback loop -- none learn whether retrieved memories helped, (2) Semantic dedup missing -- Jaccard/hash dedup misses paraphrases, (3) Windows broken in 2/6, (4) Context injection is recency-based not relevance-based, (5) Signal detection too narrow (regex misses most real decisions). Unique insights: claude-mem shows memories to human but not Claude (fatal), arscontexta's 6-phase pipeline costs 25-48K tokens per note, memory-mcp's 500-char truncation loses signal before extraction model sees it, auto-memory only captures file edits not conversation insights, claude-diary runs reflection in nearly-full context window (worst timing).

activities.description: [IN_PROGRESS] Design automatic memory capture -- detect and store significant moments
activities.details: Research complete. 3 research agents mapped the landscape (hooks, current infrastructure, signal detection patterns). 6 agents reverse-engineered community plugins. Now need to synthesize into a design and build it. The design should combine: (1) Stop/PreCompact hook signal detection with broad regex pre-filter + structural validation, (2) Fresh subprocess extraction using transcript_path, (3) Quality gate as the final filter, (4) Feedback loop connecting retrieval usefulness back to memory scoring, (5) Prompt-relevant injection in UserPromptSubmit.

activities.description: [WIN] Method: Thin-Slice Iteration -- build smallest working piece, test on real data, learn, expand
activities.details: New method developed in S53 for exploratory design where the right answer isn't known. Steps: (1) Establish ground truth first -- manually identify what "right" looks like on real data before building anything. (2) Build the thinnest possible slice (e.g., just regex patterns). (3) Run it against real data (actual session transcript). (4) Score: what did it catch, what did it miss, what were false positives. (5) Iterate on the gaps. Different from parallel build (for known-scope work) and research sprints (for landscape mapping). This method is for when you're inventing something new. First experiment: signal detector on S53 transcript caught shifts/corrections/conclusions but missed bug discoveries, test results, and Pat's direct instructions.

First live fire confirmed -- detected a verification signal and injected the nudge. PreCompact hook does a final flush before compression. All Windows-first (pathToFileURL, no /tmp, no fcntl).

activities.description: [PAIN] Signal nudge appeared but Claude still didn't act on it until Pat said to
activities.details: The auto-capture system successfully detected a signal and injected UNCAPTURED SIGNALS into Claude's context. But Claude read the nudge, acknowledged it existed, and kept talking about committing code instead of stopping to store the memory. Pat had to explicitly say 'so we now actually stop and update.' The nudge works as infrastructure but Claude needs to treat it as a real action item, not background noise.

activities.description: [ARCHITECTURE] Auto-capture pipeline architecture: Stop -> Queue -> UserPromptSubmit -> Nudge
activities.details: Signal detection pipeline built in S53. Flow: (1) Stop hook reads last_assistant_message, runs regex pre-filter across 8 signal types, validates structurally, queues to signal-queue.json. (2) UserPromptSubmit hook reads queue, also detects user pushback/instructions in current prompt, formats UNCAPTURED SIGNALS nudge with excerpts and confidence levels, injects into Claude's context, flushes queue. (3) PreCompact hook does final sweep before context compression. Files: signal-detector.mjs (patterns + queue), stop-thought.mjs (detection), user-prompt.mjs (injection), pre-compact.mjs (final flush). All Windows-first.

activities.description: [FACT] 5 universal flaws shared by ALL community memory plugins
activities.details: From reverse-engineering 6 plugins (claude-diary, claude-mem, auto-memory, memory-mcp, arscontexta, claude-memory): (1) No feedback loop -- none measure if retrieved memories helped. (5) No quality gate -- everything gets stored regardless of value. Our brain engine addresses 4 of 5 (quality gate, staleness/pruning, contradiction detection exists but unwired, synaptic tracking exists but unused). The feedback loop is the remaining gap and our first-mover opportunity.

activities.description: Task: Research: optimal multi-turn context strategies for Qwen boardroom calls
activities.details: Current approach: stateless API calls with full chat history stuffed into each prompt. Pat questions if this is effective. activities.description: [IN_PROGRESS] Research: optimal multi-turn context strategies for Qwen boardroom calls
[FACT] Research: multi-agent context management -- findings and recommendations
activities.details: 6-agent research sprint on boardroom context strategies. Key findings: (1) Cost is negligible at our scale ($0.004/session). (2) max_tokens:100 is the #1 quality bottleneck. (3) Full history replay causes sycophancy amplification (r=0.902), groupthink (80%+ collapse), and diversity loss. (4) Blackboard/whiteboard pattern outperforms peer-to-peer chat 13-57%. (5) Less shared context = more diverse outputs. (6) Multi-agent debate gains mostly come from ensembling not debate rounds. (7) Qwen API is fully stateless -- no prefix caching via Chutes. Quick wins: raise max_tokens to 400, add round awareness, fix whiteboard regex, raise char limit to 300.

activities.description: [FACT] Boardroom quality issues: 6 concrete problems identified from research sprint
activities.details: 1. max_tokens:100 for non-thinking agents -- can't finish a thought. Fix: raise to 400. 2. No round awareness -- agents can't modulate intro vs synthesis. Fix: pass round/maxRounds to prompt. 3. Whiteboard regex broken for multiline -- only captures single-line after "posting to whiteboard:". Fix: [\s\S]+ instead of .+. 4. CHAT_CHAR_LIMIT=160 too restrictive for technical work. Fix: raise to 300. 5. Specialist agent prompts (neuro/eng/research) written for deliberation conflict with boardroom rules. Fix: boardroom-specific prompts. 6. Agent can't see its own last message separately -- causes repetition. Fix: extract and show explicitly.

activities.description: [FACT] Anti-groupthink mitigations for multi-agent systems (from research)
activities.details: Research-backed mitigations: 1. Independent initialization -- no shared history for round 1, agents form positions independently. 2. Selective history injection -- each agent sees own messages + summary of others, not full transcript. 3. Cap debate at 3 rounds then synthesize (no quality improvement beyond 3). 4. Agent diversity matters more than agent count (DMAD, ICLR 2025). 5. Majority vote (self-consistency) beats multi-round debate at same token cost for factual questions. 6. Blackboard/whiteboard pattern outperforms peer-to-peer chat 13-57% for coordination.

Test: hw_store_memory with pain type, check expectation-model.json gets created. 2. store.ts:211 -- m.links changed to (m.links ?? []) in addLink(). Test: store a memory, check activity.json for "store:linker failed" errors. Both fixes build clean but haven't been tested at runtime.

activities.description: Task: Boardroom quick wins: max_tokens, round awareness, whiteboard regex, char limit
activities.details: Implement the 4 highest-impact boardroom fixes from the research sprint: 1. runner.ts:51 -- raise max_tokens from 100 to 400 for non-thinking agents 2. runner.ts buildBoardroomPrompt -- add round number and phase guidance (round/maxRounds params, intro vs converge instructions) 3. runner.ts:182 -- fix whiteboard regex from (.+) to ([\s\S]+) for multiline capture 4. types.ts:39 -- raise CHAT_CHAR_LIMIT from 160 to 300 Also: show agent's own last message separately in prompt to prevent repetition.

activities.description: Task: Boardroom anti-groupthink: independent initialization + selective history
activities.details: Restructure runBoardroom into phases based on research findings: Phase 1 (rounds 1): Independent thinking -- each agent sees only topic + whiteboard, no chat history. Forms position independently. Phase 2 (rounds 2-3): Selective sharing -- agents see whiteboard + own prior messages + compressed summary of others' positions. NOT full transcript. Phase 3 (rounds 4+): Convergence -- synthesis round, flag disagreements as valuable. This prevents anchoring bias (r=0.902 sycophancy correlation), groupthink (80%+ collapse), and produces more diverse outputs (research: embedding similarity 0.791 -> 0.511 without shared context).

activities.description: Task: Auto-capture: add storage path so detected signals become memories automatically
activities.details: The signal detector pipeline detects and nudges but never auto-stores. Fix this gap. Options: 1. Server-side: add processSignalQueue() to MCP server that consumes high-confidence (0.7+) signals and auto-stores them via storeMemory(). Run during hw_store_memory or hw_retrieve_memories calls. 2. Qwen quality gate: for 0.5-0.7 signals, send excerpt to Qwen ("is this worth storing? yes/no") before storing. Cheap per-signal cost. 3. Keep nudge system for low-confidence signals but make the "STOP and evaluate" behavior automatic. Decision needed on which approach. The current system wastes detected signals -- detection without storage is waste.

activities.description: Task: Boardroom agent prompts: create boardroom-specific versions for specialist agents
activities.details: Current specialist agents (neuro-vision, neuro-impl, eng-arch, eng-impl, research-vision, research-impl) have system prompts written for adversarial deliberation. These conflict with boardroom collaboration rules -- FORMAT instructions say "2-4 sentences" which clashes with 160/300 char limit, and role framing says "argue against whatever seems obvious" which contradicts "collaborate, don't argue." Add a boardroomPrompt field to AgentDefinition type, create collaboration-focused versions of specialist prompts, fall back to systemPrompt if boardroomPrompt absent.

activities.description: [FACT] Subagent team strategy playbook -- complete framework
activities.details: Two channels: Channel A (Task tool) for real work, Channel B (boardroom) for opinions. Never mix. Agent counts: Research 4-6, Build 2-3, Audit 4, Deliberation 4-6. Always include contrarian + premortem in deliberations. Model routing: Opus for architecture/cross-module, Sonnet for all parallel work, Haiku for boardroom domain, Qwen for boardroom cognitive. Never Qwen for autonomous multi-file editing. Spawn agents only when: tasks are genuinely independent, would take 10+ min sequentially, and decomposition is clear. Every parallel build needs live-app verification, not just build. Synthesis: research=conclusions+sources, build=dependency-ordered merge+live test, audit=severity-ranked action list, deliberation=hw_record_decision required.

activities.description: [DECISION] Experiment result: Qwen boardroom as adversarial reviewer for Claude audit
activities.details: Ran 4 Claude subagents (UI/UX, Architecture, Cognitive, Value/ROI) for deep audit, then 4 Qwen agents (Devil's Advocate, Pragmatist, Minimalist, Builder) to challenge findings. Devil's Advocate kept repeating "resilience" and "fallback" without substantiation. No agent could cite code or provide evidence. (4) Groupthink check: Devil's Advocate was contrarian but shallow -- kept asserting things are "fallbacks" with no evidence. Pragmatist and Builder converged quickly. Minimalist was the strongest voice. VERDICT: Qwen boardroom adds marginal value for audit review. Better suited for brainstorming/ideation than code-level analysis. The 160-char limit kills depth. For future audits, skip the boardroom step.

activities.description:
Boardroom: CONTEXT: You are senior developers on the Hello World project -- an autonomous AI workspace where Claude operates as the primary developer. The brain memory system is the core differentiator: tiered memory (pain/win/fact/decision/architecture), quality gate scoring, cortex learning, pruning, and reflection.

FILES YOU BUILT:
- scoring.ts: decay rates per type, severity multipliers, access boost, failure penalties, supersededBy handling, contradiction detection via tag overlap
- pruner.ts: archives memories below minScore or past maxStaleDays, physically removes from active pool
- cortex-learner.ts: learns word->tag mappings from retrieval gaps, substring matching, 2-observation minimum, no unlearn path
- reflection.ts: generates predictions, compares to outcomes, stores "Surprise" memories as new records linked to originals

EXTERNAL AUDIT FINDINGS (from 4 independent Qwen analysts):

1. RECONSOLIDATION MISSING (all 4 agreed): Memories are immutable after creation. When retrieved, content never updates -- only accessCount/lastAccessed change. Reflections create NEW memories instead of updating originals. This causes fragmentation: "correction chains" instead of refined knowledge.

2. SAFETY ATROPHY: Pain memories decay (half-life 28 days) and get pruned when score drops below threshold. The knowledge that prevents failures gets deleted for being "stale" -- guaranteeing recurrence of past catastrophes.

3. CORTEX POISONING: cortex-learner uses substring matching (string.includes) with only 2 observations needed. Wrong associations get baked in at 0.95 confidence with no negative feedback or unlearn path. Creates epistemic echo chambers.

4. CONTRADICTION DETECTION BRITTLE: findContradictions requires minTagOverlap=2 and exact type match. Two conflicting facts with different tags coexist without detection. "Use V1" and "Use V2" both survive if tagged differently.

5. QUALITY GATE REWARDS VERBOSITY: computeQualityScore gives +0.2 for detailLength > 200. Incentivizes padding over precision. Short sharp rules score lower than verbose fluff.

6. ARCHIVE IS AMNESIA: pruner physically removes memories. Archived memories can't influence behavior (no priming). Biological forgetting is retrieval failure, not deletion.

7. NO CONTEXTUAL RETRIEVAL: scoring is global (time + access frequency), not query-dependent. A 2-year-old architecture memory scores low even when the current query is exactly about that architecture.

8. REFLECTION RECURSION RISK: No maxReflectionDepth or cooldown. Reflections on reflections could create storms.

DISCUSS: Which findings are actionable now vs theoretical? What's the implementation priority? What can we fix without breaking the system? Are any findings wrong or misunderstanding our constraints (single-user JSON file system, not distributed)?

An external audit found 8 issues:
1. RECONSOLIDATION MISSING: Memories are immutable. Reflections create new records instead of updating originals. Causes correction chains.
2. SAFETY ATROPHY: Pain memories decay (28-day half-life) and get pruned. Safety knowledge deleted for being "stale."
3. CORTEX POISONING: substring matching + 2 observations = wrong associations at 0.95 confidence, no unlearn path.
4. CONTRADICTION DETECTION BRITTLE: requires 2 tag overlap + exact type match. Different tags = no detection.
5. QUALITY GATE REWARDS VERBOSITY: +0.2 for detailLength > 200. Padding > precision.
6. ARCHIVE IS AMNESIA: pruner deletes memories. No priming from archived memories.

Panel: STRUCTURED DELIBERATION -- ROUND 2: ADDRESS EACH OTHER'S OPINIONS

You are continuing a structured debate about the Hello World brain memory system audit findings. In Round 1, three experts stated their positions. Now you must:

1. Read all three Round 1 opinions below
2. Address each of the other two experts' positions -- where you agree, where you disagree, and why
3. Form your UPDATED opinion based on hearing the others
4. Vote: CONCLUDE (we have enough consensus to act) or CONTINUE (need more discussion)

---
ROUND 1 OPINIONS:

**NOVA (Brain Architect):**
- Finding 1 (Reconsolidation): PARTIALLY AGREE -- immutability was intentional for JSON safety, but correction chains bloat the active set
- Finding 2 (Safety Atrophy): AGREE -- uniform decay rates cause safety constraints to expire
- Finding 3 (Cortex Poisoning): AGREE -- v1 substring matching too naive, no negative reinforcement
- Finding 4 (Contradiction Detection): DISAGREE -- semantic detection is over-engineering for <500 memories
- Finding 5 (Verbosity): AGREE -- detailLength > 200 is a flawed metric
- Finding 6 (Archive Amnesia): PARTIALLY AGREE -- archive exists but retrieval never queries it
- Finding 7 (Contextual Retrieval): AGREE -- global scoring reduces precision
- Finding 8 (Reflection Recursion): AGREE -- needs maxReflectionDepth
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy fix (tag-based decay exemption), Contextual Retrieval (query-dependent scoring), Cortex Poisoning (raise to 3 obs + negative feedback)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 4 -- contradiction detection is fine for our scale

**FORGE (Systems Engineer):**
- Finding 1: PARTIALLY AGREE -- immutability safer for JSON, need better supersededBy handling
- Finding 2: AGREE -- exempt safety-tagged memories from pruning
- Finding 3: AGREE -- 0.95 confidence on 2 observations is statistically unsound
- Finding 4: DISAGREE -- fuzzy matching adds complexity and false positives at our scale
- Finding 5: AGREE -- remove detailLength bonus immediately
- Finding 6: AGREE -- archive exists but retrieval ignores it
- Finding 7: PARTIALLY AGREE -- tag-match boost yes, semantic scoring is YAGNI
- Finding 8: AGREE -- needs MAX_REFLECTION_DEPTH = 3
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy (exempt from pruning), Reflection Recursion guard (crash risk), Quality Gate fix (remove verbosity bonus)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 4 -- exact matching is deterministic and debuggable

**SAGE (Product Strategist):**
- Finding 1: AGREE -- immutable corrections create conflicting truth states
- Finding 2: AGREE -- deleting pain signals destroys user trust
- Finding 3: AGREE -- confidently wrong is worse than unsure
- Finding 4: AGREE -- brittle tag matching lets semantic contradictions through
- Finding 5: AGREE -- degrades signal-to-noise ratio
- Finding 6: PARTIALLY AGREE -- pruning needed for performance, but need cold-storage retrieval
- Finding 7: AGREE -- global scoring fails to surface relevant context
- Finding 8: AGREE -- crash risk for single-threaded app
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy (add decay_exempt flag + UI lock icon), Contextual Retrieval (TF-IDF or embedding similarity), Cortex Poisoning (probationary period + unlearn path)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 6 -- pruning is a feature, amnesia is a retrieval bug

activities.description:
Panel panel_4da54f60: STRUCTURED DELIBERATION -- ROUND 2: ADDRESS EACH OTHER'S OPINIONS

You are continuing a structured debate about the Hello World brain memory system audit findings. In Round 1, three experts stated their positions. Now you must:

1. Read all three Round 1 opinions below
2. Address each of the other two experts' positions -- where you agree, where you disagree, and why
3. Form your UPDATED opinion based on hearing the others
4. Vote: CONCLUDE (we have enough consensus to act) or CONTINUE (need more discussion)

---
ROUND 1 OPINIONS:

**NOVA (Brain Architect):**
- Finding 1 (Reconsolidation): PARTIALLY AGREE -- immutability was intentional for JSON safety, but correction chains bloat the active set
- Finding 2 (Safety Atrophy): AGREE -- uniform decay rates cause safety constraints to expire
- Finding 3 (Cortex Poisoning): AGREE -- v1 substring matching too naive, no negative reinforcement
- Finding 4 (Contradiction Detection): DISAGREE -- semantic detection is over-engineering for <500 memories
- Finding 5 (Verbosity): AGREE -- detailLength > 200 is a flawed metric
- Finding 6 (Archive Amnesia): PARTIALLY AGREE -- archive exists but retrieval never queries it
- Finding 7 (Contextual Retrieval): AGREE -- global scoring reduces precision
- Finding 8 (Reflection Recursion): AGREE -- needs maxReflectionDepth
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy fix (tag-based decay exemption), Contextual Retrieval (query-dependent scoring), Cortex Poisoning (raise to 3 obs + negative feedback)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 4 -- contradiction detection is fine for our scale

**FORGE (Systems Engineer):**
- Finding 1: PARTIALLY AGREE -- immutability safer for JSON, need better supersededBy handling
- Finding 2: AGREE -- exempt safety-tagged memories from pruning
- Finding 3: AGREE -- 0.95 confidence on 2 observations is statistically unsound
- Finding 4: DISAGREE -- fuzzy matching adds complexity and false positives at our scale
- Finding 5: AGREE -- remove detailLength bonus immediately
- Finding 6: AGREE -- archive exists but retrieval ignores it
- Finding 7: PARTIALLY AGREE -- tag-match boost yes, semantic scoring is YAGNI
- Finding 8: AGREE -- needs MAX_REFLECTION_DEPTH = 3
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy (exempt from pruning), Reflection Recursion guard (crash risk), Quality Gate fix (remove verbosity bonus)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 4 -- exact matching is deterministic and debuggable

**SAGE (Product Strategist):**
- Finding 1: AGREE -- immutable corrections create conflicting truth states
- Finding 2: AGREE -- deleting pain signals destroys user trust
- Finding 3: AGREE -- confidently wrong is worse than unsure
- Finding 4: AGREE -- brittle tag matching lets semantic contradictions through
- Finding 5: AGREE -- degrades signal-to-noise ratio
- Finding 6: PARTIALLY AGREE -- pruning needed for performance, but need cold-storage retrieval
- Finding 7: AGREE -- global scoring fails to surface relevant context
- Finding 8: AGREE -- crash risk for single-threaded app
- TOP 3: Safety Atrophy (add decay_exempt flag + UI lock icon), Contextual Retrieval (TF-IDF or embedding similarity), Cortex Poisoning (probationary period + unlearn path)
- BIGGEST DISAGREEMENT: Finding 6 -- pruning is a feature, amnesia is a retrieval bug

activities.description: Surprise detected (expectedness: 0.58): Unexpected failure: Deliberation MCP tools deleted in Session 48 Brain Magnum Opus rewrite
[WIN] Safeguard: PostToolUse hook blocks deletion of deliberation tools from server.ts
activities.details: verify-deliberation-tools.mjs runs as a PostToolUse hook after every Edit/Write to server.ts. It reads the file and checks for all 13 required deliberation tool registrations. If any are missing, it exits with code 1 (blocking the edit) and prints a clear error message. This was added after Session 48 accidentally deleted all deliberation tools during the Brain Magnum Opus refactor. The hook is registered in .claude/settings.json.

Total cost: ~25K tokens across 2 rounds. More effective than boardroom chat (which has timeout issues with Claude agents).

[FACT] Brain memory audit: 6 consensus findings from 7-agent external review
activities.details: 4 Qwen analysts + 3 Claude agents reviewed scoring.ts, pruner.ts, cortex-learner.ts, reflection.ts. Unanimous findings: (1) Safety Atrophy is P0 -- pain memories decay and get pruned, add decay_exempt flag. (2) Reflection recursion needs MAX_REFLECTION_DEPTH=3. (3) Cortex poisoning -- raise observation threshold 2->3, add negative feedback. (4) Remove verbosity bonus (detailLength>200 = +0.2). (5) Contextual retrieval -- add tag-boosting at query time. (6) Archive retrieval -- query archive on cache miss. Disagreements: contradiction detection (2 say over-engineering, 1 says needed), reconsolidation (all say partially needed but immutability has value for JSON safety).
